Steeeeve

http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,351608,00.html
 
 
 A Yale student who claims she artificially inseminated herself "as often as possible" and then took drugs to induce miscarriages for her senior art project says she will showcase the stomach-turning display next week - complete with her own blood samples and videos from the terminated possible pregnancies.

 
 I'm not even sure what to say...emoticon_ic emoticon_frazzled emoticon_xdonno

post_info.post_title: Seriously?  This seems a little sick

daewoo

Lets not forget bizarre. Certainly bizarre. 
 And yucky...for lack of a better term.
Archangel

http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,351608,00.html
 
 
 
 I'm not even sure what to say...emoticon_ic emoticon_frazzled emoticon_xdonno

 
 What would you expect from a person who was raised in a culture of death where the destruction of the unborn comes as naturally as taking a pill? My only surprise is that people are shocked that this could happen in this generation.
daewoo

Culture of death??
 
 I have heard of a murder cult before, but what exactly is a culture of death???
jitobear
That is disgusting. However - artificial insemination does not have the highest success rate, so it is a tad hard to believe.
Phyllis

It appears that this whole thing was a hoax.
 
 New York Sun:
 
 
"Ms. Shvarts is engaged in performance art," a Yale spokeswoman, Helaine Klasky, said. "She stated to three senior Yale University officials today, including two deans, that she did not impregnate herself and that she did not induce any miscarriages. The entire project is an art piece, a creative fiction designed to draw attention to the ambiguity surrounding form and function of a woman’s body."
 
 Ms. Klasky went on to suggest that Yale would not have permitted a project of the sort described in the student newspaper. "Had these acts been real, they would have violated basic ethical standards and raised serious mental and physical health concerns."

 
 I love this part: "Had these acts been real, they would have violated basic ethical standards and raised serious mental and physical health concerns." Well, even if they weren't real, I still think it raises serious mental health concerns.
 
 More:
 
 
 Yale University officials issued a strongly worded statement Thursday night explaining that a student's shocking claim that she had artificially inseminated herself "as often as possible" and then took drugs to induce miscarriages for her senior art project was "creative fiction."

 In other words, she lied. This type of thing really makes Yale look great. Perhaps this is the reason that Justice Thomas has a 15 cent sticker on his Yale Law degree?
Steeeeve
Poor reporting on the part of Fox News I suppose (and others)...good thing that is cleared up from sick and bizarre to just untrue but sick and bizarre
daewoo

Poor reporting on the part of Fox News I suppose (and others)...good thing that is cleared up from sick and bizarre to just untrue but sick and bizarre

 
 You have forgotten "yucky" again. 
 
 True or not, who in the world would want to go see that??? That is just gross.
Archangel

Culture of death??
 
 I have heard of a murder cult before, but what exactly is a culture of death???

 
 I was referring to a generation that was raised in a culture that promoted abortion as an acceptable way to dispose of unwanted babies. A generation that can produce a woman like this art student who can do such a project without feeling any personal loss or empathy for the image she is portraying through her art. That is a culture of death, or at least what I meant when i used the phrase.
 
 Any generation that can create images of aborted fetuses/embryos as art belongs to a culture of death. Just as the Natzis made lamp shades out of the flesh of jews, so is this imagery equally as sick, and the statement it makes about this generation is just as disturbing as the lamp shades made about the Natzi culture.

You have forgotten "yucky" again. 
 
 True or not, who in the world would want to go see that??? That is just gross.

 
 Haha, you covered yucky very well so I didn't think I needed to add that. Really nothing good came out of this story.

 Any generation that can create images of aborted fetuses/embryos as art belongs to a culture of death. Just as the Natzis made lamp shades out of the flesh of jews, so is this imagery equally as sick, and the statement it makes about this generation is just as disturbing as the lamp shades made about the Natzi culture.

 
 *cough*Godwin*cough*
 
 I fail to see how simply because the dead thing is a fetus any more suggests a culture of death than, say, pictures of plague victims, as appear in some mediaeval art, or art that features scenes celebrating hunting.
Phyllis

Hold your horses folks. Ms. Shvarts is disputing Yale's claim that she was merely engaging in "creative fiction" (or, in other words, a lie).
 
 Yale Daily News:
 
 
But Shvarts stood by her project, calling the University’s statement “ultimately inaccurate.”
 
 ...
 
 But Shvarts reiterated Thursday that she repeatedly use [sic] a needleless syringe to insert semen into herself. At the end of her menstrual cycle, she took abortifacient herbs to induce bleeding, she said. She said she does not know whether or not she was ever pregnant. 

 It's easy to see, I think, why Yale would be eager to distance itself from this whole thing. I wonder if we'll ever find out the truth.
Shooterandproud
Eh, I'm more worried about what all of the miscarriges are doing to that poor woman's body.
